original_theorem:
A point $\overline{x}$ is a limit
point of a set $S$ if and only if there is a sequence $\{x_n\}$ of points
in $S$ such that $x_n\ne\overline{x}$ for $n\ge 1,$ and
$$
\lim_{n\to\infty}x_n=\overline{x}.
$$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem accumulation_point_iff_sequence_limit
  {Î± : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Î±] [FirstCountableTopology Î±] [T1Space Î±] (S : Set Î±) (x_bar : Î±) :
  x_bar âˆˆ deriv S â†” âˆƒ (x : â„• â†’ Î±), (âˆ€ n, x n âˆˆ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ n, x n â‰  x_bar) âˆ§ Tendsto x atTop (ð“ x_bar) := by
```

import Aesop

open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem accumulation_point_iff_sequence_limit
  {Î± : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Î±] [FirstCountableTopology Î±] [T1Space Î±] (S : Set Î±) (x_bar : Î±) :
  x_bar âˆˆ deriv S â†” âˆƒ (x : â„• â†’ Î±), (âˆ€ n, x n âˆˆ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ n, x n â‰  x_bar) âˆ§ Tendsto x atTop (ð“ x_bar) := by sorry

e\overline{x}$ for all $n\ge 1,$ and $\lim_{n\to\infty}x_n=\overline{x}$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
â€¢ For each $\epsilon>0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n\ge N$, we have $0<|x_n-\overline{x}|<\epsilon$ [l1].
